title: How to Connect the Nintendo Wii to Wi–Fi

steps.headline: Power on your Nintendo Wii console and press the “A” button on your Wii remote.
steps.description: This will bring up the Wii main menu.

steps.headline: Select the “Wii” button located in the lower left corner of the screen, then select “Wii Settings.”
Select the arrow displayed on the right side of your screen.
steps.description: This will access page two of Wii System Settings.

steps.headline: Select “Connection 1: None,” or another empty connection slot.
steps.description: If all connection slots are being used, select the connection slot you want cleared, then select “Clear settings.” Your Wii cannot connect to Wi-Fi unless you use an empty connection slot.

steps.headline: Select “Wireless Connection,” then select “Search for an Access Point.”
Select “OK.” Your Wii will scan for all nearby Wi-Fi networks, and display the list of networks on-screen.
Select the wireless network to which you want to connect, then enter the network password or security key, if applicable.
steps.description: If you do not know the network password, try contacting the network administrator, enter the value displayed next to “security key” on your router, or contact the router’s manufacturer to obtain the default password.

steps.headline: Select “OK” three times at each subsequent prompt.
steps.description: This will save your wireless network settings and test the Internet connection.

steps.headline: Select “Yes” when your Wii displays a message saying the connection test was successful.
steps.description: Your Wii will now be connected to the Wi-Fi network selected.

steps.headline: Try re-entering the router’s security code if you receive error codes 51330 or 52130 after testing the Internet connection.
steps.description: These errors mean the router security code you’ve entered is incorrect.

steps.headline: Try powercycling or resetting your Wi-Fi router if your Wii is still unable to connect to the Internet after entering the correct security code.
steps.description: Powercycling the router can help refresh the network connection, whereas resetting your router will restore the router’s default factory settings and reset its username and password. Most brands of routers can be reset by pressing the “Reset” button on the front, back, or side of your router.

steps.headline: Close out applications or shut down devices that may be using an excessive amount of bandwidth on your network if your Wii is unable to connect to the Internet or experiences slowness.
steps.description: Certain applications and behaviors, such as downloading large files, may interfere with your being able to connect the Wii to Wi-Fi.

steps.headline: Try relocating furniture and metal objects away from your router and Nintendo Wii if you are unable to establish or maintain an Internet connection.
steps.description: In many cases, metal objects such as filing cabinets and electronic devices such as cordless phones can interfere with your Wi-Fi signal.

steps.headline: Contact Nintendo’s customer support team at 1-800-255-3700 if you are still unable to connect to Wi-Fi using your Wii console.
steps.description: Nintendo will guide you through additional troubleshooting, and may walk you through changing additional settings on the console. Nintendo’s customer support team is available between the hours of 6 a.m. and 7 p.m. Pacific Time, seven days per week. Alternately, navigate to Nintendo’s chat service at http://www.nintendo.com/consumer/assets/chat/chatPop.jsp?type=wifi&system=Wii&data1=, and fill out the required fields to chat with an agent from Nintendo.

text: Connecting the Wii to Wi-Fi Power on your Nintendo Wii console and press the “A” button on your Wii remote. This will bring up the Wii main menu. Select the “Wii” button located in the lower left corner of the screen, then select “Wii Settings.”  Select the arrow displayed on the right side of your screen. This will access page two of Wii System Settings. Select “Internet,” then select “Connection Settings.”  Select “Connection 1: None,” or another empty connection slot. If all connection slots are being used, select the connection slot you want cleared, then select “Clear settings.” Your Wii cannot connect to Wi-Fi unless you use an empty connection slot. Select “Wireless Connection,” then select “Search for an Access Point.”  Select “OK.” Your Wii will scan for all nearby Wi-Fi networks, and display the list of networks on-screen.  Select the wireless network to which you want to connect, then enter the network password or security key, if applicable. If you do not know the network password, try contacting the network administrator, enter the value displayed next to “security key” on your router, or contact the router’s manufacturer to obtain the default password. Select “OK” three times at each subsequent prompt. This will save your wireless network settings and test the Internet connection. Select “Yes” when your Wii displays a message saying the connection test was successful. Your Wii will now be connected to the Wi-Fi network selected. Troubleshooting Wii Wi-Fi Connectivity Try re-entering the router’s security code if you receive error codes 51330 or 52130 after testing the Internet connection. These errors mean the router security code you’ve entered is incorrect. Try powercycling or resetting your Wi-Fi router if your Wii is still unable to connect to the Internet after entering the correct security code. Powercycling the router can help refresh the network connection, whereas resetting your router will restore the router’s default factory settings and reset its username and password. Most brands of routers can be reset by pressing the “Reset” button on the front, back, or side of your router. Close out applications or shut down devices that may be using an excessive amount of bandwidth on your network if your Wii is unable to connect to the Internet or experiences slowness. Certain applications and behaviors, such as downloading large files, may interfere with your being able to connect the Wii to Wi-Fi. Try relocating furniture and metal objects away from your router and Nintendo Wii if you are unable to establish or maintain an Internet connection. In many cases, metal objects such as filing cabinets and electronic devices such as cordless phones can interfere with your Wi-Fi signal. Contact Nintendo’s customer support team at 1-800-255-3700 if you are still unable to connect to Wi-Fi using your Wii console. Nintendo will guide you through additional troubleshooting, and may walk you through changing additional settings on the console. Nintendo’s customer support team is available between the hours of 6 a.m. and 7 p.m. Pacific Time, seven days per week. Alternately, navigate to Nintendo’s chat service at http://www.nintendo.com/consumer/assets/chat/chatPop.jsp?type=wifi&system=Wii&data1=, and fill out the required fields to chat with an agent from Nintendo.
